topics.body:
I thought of something interesting; I was reading the authoritarian thread a minute ago, for those of you that don't know we had a stormfront guy come on claiming all this bullcrap that was 20 years debunked evolutionary wise, the reason why it's interesting though is that say 20 years ago people thought there was a direct evolution from our ancestors to humans today.  Today we know that's a bunch of crap cause humans didn't come from one ancestor, but rather that we had dozens of ancestors and that cause we all fucked and pop comes homo sapiens.

Why is this important?  Well now that we have genetic engineering, we're working on biomechatronics, we have small scale printed organs and such basically pretty soon we're going to have our hands on the equivalent of a billion years of evolution as a lab tool for consumers that want to look "cool" or such.

What do I think is going to be after cybernetics?  Probably synthetic biology.  What do I mean by synthetic biology?  If we develop synthetic biology then "evolution" is reduced to a metaphorical software update.


Tl:dr; I wouldn't be surprised if in say 500 years "humans" aren't genetically human, but rather still to some degree look "humanish" cause if you give people the ability to change their genetic structure every which way and replace out every part chances are the majority of people will choose to be changed based on looks rather than performance.

Tl:dr of tl:dr; It's more likely that people will want to be walking around with say bunny ears rather than have say twenty arms and I doubt people in say 500 years will look completely different cause most people would rather look good than be able to jump a building.
